reporting-org.narrative: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands

title.narrative: JER Opening Gate to the Quality Media

description.narrative: The goal of the project is to enhance the role of the self-regulation and media literacy in strengthening the segment of quality media in Armenia and contributing to the consistent reform in the information sphere. The Project design is based on integrated approach towards three groups of activities. The first one is directed at the institutionalization of Media Ethics Observatory (MEO), an experimental self-regulation body established at the initiative of Yerevan Press Club. The process of institutionalization includes support to the regular operation of MEO – issuing judgments on complaints against media, mediation of information disputes, development of thematic ethical guidelines. Strengthening of MEO will be en-sured also due to “twinning” with Raad voor de Journalistiek and utilizing experience of the Netherlands and other European countries in media self-regulation, including a study visit to the Netherlands. Secretary of the Raad voor de Jouranlistike – Mrs Daphne Koene - has agreed to be project consultant. More Armenian media joining self-regulation initiative, growing num-ber of complaints as manifestation of public trust, and introduc-tion of “Quality marker”, exposing commitment of certain seg-ment of the industry to the responsible journalism will be the indicators of the success of the Project. The second group of activities includes collection of data on the major challenges for integrity of media. This will be achieved through the monitoring based on specifically designed methodology. The monitoring and the results of MEO operation will allow developing consistent recommendations for the im-provement of media legislation and the government’s policy in the information sphere. The third group of activities will compose a campaign for media literacy and consumers’ demand of quality, reliable con-tent. Meetings with the media audiences and establishment of annual Forum will aim to address the peculiarities of Armenian media market and mechanisms for its healthy operation. “Aquarium” sessions of MEO will help to familiarize wider public with self-regulation concept. Creative presence of the Project in the social networks through author’s blogs will to a certain ex-tent contribute to the spread of ethical principles not only in the traditional but also in the new media. Efficient interaction of the listed Project components promises long awaited change in Armenian information ecosystem. This project also has a potential of turning into a regional initia-tive through cooperation of YPG and Georgian Charter of Jour-nalistic Ethics (which received its small MATRA KAP grant from NL TBI in about 2010), and other Georgian NGO’s working on freedom of expression and media literacy.
